attributes.title: Trolls Psyc 2017
attributes.description:
The Dark Tetrad is made up of four different personalities: Machiavellianism, narcissism, psychopathy, and sadism. We encounter these personalities every day; the Machiavellian who has tricked you into giving something up, the narcissist who constantly brags about themselves, the subclinical psychopath who has physically hurt you, and the sadist who hurts people for fun. Cyberbullying is prominent in today’s society, as well as other online behaviors such as trolling. Trolling involves being deceptive online for no reason and towards people the person doesn’t know, and tricking people into humiliating themselves (Buckels, Trapnell, & Paulhus, 2014). Online trolls are individuals who partake in deceptive, destructive, or disruptive behavior in a social setting on the Internet with no apparent instrumental purpose (Buckels, Trapnell & Paulhus, 2014). There are many possible predictors of social media trolling behavior, specifically psychosocial disorders. As these individuals have no apparent purpose, we need an explanation for the behavior displayed by these online trolls is searched for. With research, one can gain an understanding of these behaviors. To begin to conduct research in order to understand trolling behaviors, one has to understand why these behaviors are prevalent in certain individuals. Research also indicates that those who are narcissists and those with antisocial personality disorder use social media more often than others (Rosen, Whaling, Rab, Carrier & Cheever, 2013). An online “troll” is a separate personality related entity, and in order to understand this identity, one must understand the self- presentation that’s goes into its construction (Fox & Rooney, 2015).

 

The behavior displayed by trolls over the Internet can not only give a lot of insight into the psychosocial disorders an individual may or may not possess or develop, but can also have severe effects on the individual on the receiving end of the trolls’ malicious behavior. By understanding the psychosocial predictors of social media trolling, the online behavior may be prevented along with its substantial and negative consequences to its victims (Howard, Zolnierek, Critz, Dailey & Ceballos, 2019). There is a relationship believed to be between the Big Five personality traits, Dark Triad traits, and sadism with bullying and/ or cyberbullying (van Geel, Goemans, Toprak & Vedder, 2017).If there is a relation between theses personality disorders and cyberbullying, as well as with increased social media use, then the negative behavior of online trolls can be predicted and prevented. This would solve the issue of the negative consequences trolling can have, while addressing the psychosocial disorder the ‘troll’ is experiencing. Understanding the meaning of an online “troll” and what traits they possess can also help society establish constructs of identity, as traits from the Dark Triad can manifest in both trolls and victims (Linton & Power, 2013).

q1.value: Ashley Evans, Katie Gatewood, Tai Lambert

q2.value: Individuals who participate more in negative social media interactions are more likely to possess or develop the personality disorders which make up the Dark Tetrad.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Our study will be measuring trait comparison with a single group of internet users, and how their social media interactions serve as predictors for the possession of personality traits within the Dark Triad. Participants will first be asked to take the the Big Five Inventory, a self report measure used to assess extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism, and openness to experience. Afterwards, they will take the Short Dark Triad scale, which assesses narcissistic, Machiavellianism, and psychopathic traits. Sadism will be measured using the Comprehensive Assessment of Sadistic Tendencies, another self report measure that looks at a broader range of subtypes under the sadistic trait. All of the personality assessments are Likert scale questionnaires. To measure internet behavior, participants will be given a questionnaire that calls for them to estimate how much time they spend on the internet, whether they post comments on websites, and how many hours a day they spend posting on websites. To measure trolling as a subunit under internet behavior, participants will also be given a 5-point Likert scale questionnaire called the Global Assessment of Internet Trolling, containing items like: ‘‘I like to troll people in forums or the comments section of websites’’, and ‘‘The more beautiful and pure a thing is, the more satisfying it is to corrupt.”

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value: Two large samples of participants will be recruited from the US on Amazon's Mechanical Turk website (MTurk; http://www.mturk.com) and students from a psychology department at Louisiana State University. Participants are to be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk Website will receive $.50 in compensation for their time and the participating LSU psychology students will receive extra credit for their participation in the study.

q11.value: We will collect two large samples online. The first sample will be from a pool of LSU psychology students with a target size of 188. The second sample will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk website (MTurk; http.//www.mturk.com) with a target size of 609. These numbers are inspired by the original study we will be replicating.

q13.value: Stopping rule will not be applied, no sequential analysis will be used in the sampling process.

question.value: Variables that will be measured include extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism, openness, narcissism, Machiavellianism, sub-clinical psychopathy, sadism, direct physical sadism, direct verbal sadism, vicarious sadism, hours spent per day on the internet, commenting frequency, enjoyment of debating, chatting, trolling and making friends, and trolling tendencies.

To analyze our results we will run Pearson correlations between personality traits, commenting frequency, and enjoyment of specified activities. We will also run a Pearson correlation between personality traits and commenting frequency while controlling for overall internet use. These are the tests run in the original study that we will be replicating.

q19.value: Each analyses will be a two-tailed test. We will use the criterion of p>.05, p>.01, and p>.001. When comparing multiple conditions, we will run regression analyses and mediation analyses.

q20.value: Outliers will be included in the analysis, and a separate analyses without the outlier will also be conducted in order to compare the two outcomes. An explanation will be provided as to why any data would be considered an outlier and the difference that removing the outlier makes in the outcome.

q21.value: If a subject does not answer all of the questions, the subject's data will not be included in the analysis.

q23.value: We will be replicating the study of Buckels, E. E., et al. Trolls just want to have fun. Personality and Individual Differences (2014), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.paid.2014.01.016

attributes.title: To intervene or not to intervene? How parents’ beliefs influence their agreement with achievement-related parenting practices
attributes.description: Previous research has identified parents as having an important influence on children's achievement motivation, particularly through what they say (e.g., the praise they give their children when they succeed) and do (e.g., whether or not they intervene when their child experiences academic difficulty). However, little work has examined the beliefs underlying these parenting practices. The present study aims to investigate whether general beliefs about the necessity of parental intervention predict parents' endorsement of specific achievement-related practices that involve high or low parental intervention.

q2.value:
In previous pilot work utilizing the same design described here, we hypothesized that there would be a crossover interaction between overall scores on our novel parental belief measure [where higher scores indicate greater endorsement of the idea that parental intervention is necessary for a young adult child's success; items adapted from Padilla-Walker & Nelson, 2012] and the type of parental practice endorsed in achievement-related scenarios (either high or low intervention). Specifically, in pilot work, we expected that higher scores on the belief measure would predict higher agreement with high intervention practices but lower agreement with low intervention practices. Our initial pilot work supported the former prediction, but not the latter - that is, higher scores on the belief measure predicted higher agreement with high intervention practices, but belief score did not predict agreement with low intervention practices. 

We think that these findings are likely due to the fact that we intentionally did not design our low intervention items to be as extreme as many of our high intervention items. That is, while many of our high intervention items involved more extreme parental intervention (e.g., 'taking over' and doing work on behalf of the child), our low intervention items were intended to embody a more autonomy-supportive approach (e.g., encouraging the child to work independently, but being available for help if needed). Considering these practices on a spectrum from extremely low to extremely high parental intervention, the low intervention practices we presented to parents are quite far from the extremely low (i.e., neglectful) end of the spectrum, whereas the high intervention practices we used are relatively closer to the extremely high end of the spectrum. Because the study to which this preregistration pertains aims to replicate this pilot work (using the same high and low intervention items), our primary hypothesis follows accordingly.

H1: There will be an interaction between overall scores on a novel parent belief measure [where higher scores indicate greater endorsement of the idea that parental intervention is necessary for a young adult child’s success; items adapted from Padilla-Walker & Nelson, 2012] and type of parental practice (either high or low intervention) endorsed for specific achievement-related scenarios.

H1a: Higher scores on the belief measure will predict higher agreement with high intervention   practices.
H1b: Higher scores on the belief measure will not predict agreement with low intervention practices.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a within-subjects design with a single factor of parental practice type (either high or low parental intervention).

q7.value: All participants will be presented with four scenarios involving a generic parent and their high-school age child; the order in which these scenarios are presented will be randomized across subjects. After each scenario, participants will be asked to rate their agreement with number of potential parental responses/practices (varying in whether they involve high or low parental intervention); within each scenario, the order in which participants see and rate these responses will be randomized across participants. The order of items that comprise the parent belief measure (which will assess general beliefs about parental intervention) will also be randomized across participants. All randomization will be done via appropriate settings in Qualtrics (e.g., question and block randomization).

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited using CloudResearch, an online platform for recruiting participants from Amazon's Mechanical Turk. The study will only be advertised to individuals who are over 18 years of age and reside in the United States. Additionally, only those whose identity as parents has been verified by CloudResearch will be able to participate. A screener question placed prior to the consent page of our survey will filter out those who do **not** report having at least one child between the ages of 14 and 18 years from participation. Those who are eligible to complete the survey and consent to do so will be paid $3.00 for their time.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants.

q12.value: Our chosen sample size is based on a power analysis conducted using the 'simr' package. Our estimated effect size was drawn from our prior pilot research. This analysis indicated that 100 participants was adequate for achieving a minimum of 80% power for a medium effect size with a standard alpha of .05.

q13.value: Our target sample will be included in the setup of our CloudResearch study; therefore, once 100 participants have been recruited and have confirmed their completion of the survey, data collection will end.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of the parental practices/responses rated by parents, such that some involve high parental intervention, and some involve low parental intervention. As described previously, participants will be asked to rate several potential responses a parent might have to each of four achievement-related scenarios; these responses will vary in whether they involve high parental intervention (e.g., taking over and completing a task for their child) or low parental intervention (e.g., letting the child complete the task independently). We designed these responses to be high or low in parental intervention based on previous literature examining the effects of parental intervention on children's achievement motivation.

Our outcome variables will be 1) participants' ratings of the potential parental responses to each of the four achievement-related scenarios and 2) participants' ratings of the items on the parent belief scale (which will assess the extent to which they believe that parental intervention is necessary for a young adult child's success). 

Participants' scenario ratings will be assessed via 7-point Likert scales (one for each item), anchored by 1 ('strongly disagree') and 7 ('strongly agree'). 

Participants' ratings of belief scale items will be assessed via 7-point Likert scales, anchored by two statements: one asserting that a young adult is responsible for a particular decision or action (e.g., "A young adult needs to make important decisions (e.g., where they work, where they live, what classes they should take)), and one asserting that a parent is responsible for a particular decision or action (e.g., "A parent needs to make important decisions on behalf of their young adult child (e.g., where they work, where they live, what classes they should take)).

Participants' responses to the six items that comprise the parent belief measure will be averaged to generate a mean belief score (where a higher score indicates believing to a greater extent that parental intervention is necessary for a young adult's success).

We will use both frequentist (linear mixed effects models) and Bayesian (Bayesian ordinal regression models) to analyze our results.

Our predictor variables will as follows: participants' belief score (entered as a continuous variable), the type of parental response (either high or low intervention; entered as a categorical variable), the interaction between the two (i.e., the interaction between belief score and parental response type), and scenario. Since we used a repeated measures design, we will also include a random intercept of participant (1 | participant). Our dependent variable will be participants' ratings of the potential parental responses to the scenarios (included as a continuous variable in the linear mixed effects model and as an ordinal variable in the Bayesian ordinal regression model).

A note on our inclusion of 'scenario' as a fixed effect: While our key hypotheses do not pertain to how participants' ratings of parental practices differ across scenarios, pilot work indicated that there were not enough scenarios to achieve a reliable estimate of the variance when scenario was entered as a random effect. This is consistent with literature suggesting that you need at least 5 levels (if not more) of a variable to achieve a precise and robust estimate of variance when it is entered as a random effect (see Gelman & Hill, 2007). We decided to keep scenario in our models as a fixed effect in order to still account for any potential effect of scenario.

q19.value:
In our frequentist analysis, we will use the standard p < .05 criteria for determining whether a model containing the interaction between participants' belief score and the type of parental response (high or low on parental intervention) explains significantly more of the variance than a model containing the same predictors (described in the 'Statistical Models' section above) but no interaction term. We will also use p < .05 to evaluate the significance of individual predictors, including our key interaction of interest between belief score and type of parental response.

In our Bayesian analysis, we will use a Bayes factor for determining whether the observed data are more probable under the model containing the interaction between participants' belief score and the type of parental response (high or low on parental intervention) than the model containing the same predictors but no interaction term. We will use the decision thresholds specified by Jeffreys (1961). To evaluate the effect of individual predictors, we will rely on 95% credible intervals.

q20.value: Data will be excluded from participants who fail a bot check (where they will be asked to identify an image) or an attention check (where they will be asked to recall a prominent theme from one of the four scenarios they are asked to read).

q21.value: All of the key questions in our survey (i.e., ratings of potential parental practices and belief scale items) will be required for proceeding within the survey, and so we do not anticipate missing data from those items. Participants who elect not to answer any or all of the optional demographic questions at the end of the survey will not be excluded from final analyses (unless those analyses involve the demographic information they have elected not to provide).

q22.value:
Our exploratory analyses will examine whether demographic variables measured in the study (e.g., parent gender, parent education level, household income) moderate the relationships between the predictors and our primary dependent variable (parents' ratings of the potential parental responses to the scenarios).

In addition, we will explore the effects of our predictors for different levels of the Likert scale parents used to rate the scenario items; for instance, we will examine whether the effect of overall belief score is stronger at extreme values of the Likert scale (such as 'strongly agree') and whether the interaction between belief score and item type (strong or minimal intervention) is stronger for these extreme values (vs. moderate values, such as 'somewhat disagree' or 'somewhat agree').

registration_responses.q2:
In previous pilot work utilizing the same design described here, we hypothesized that there would be a crossover interaction between overall scores on our novel parental belief measure [where higher scores indicate greater endorsement of the idea that parental intervention is necessary for a young adult child's success; items adapted from Padilla-Walker & Nelson, 2012] and the type of parental practice endorsed in achievement-related scenarios (either high or low intervention). Specifically, in pilot work, we expected that higher scores on the belief measure would predict higher agreement with high intervention practices but lower agreement with low intervention practices. Our initial pilot work supported the former prediction, but not the latter - that is, higher scores on the belief measure predicted higher agreement with high intervention practices, but belief score did not predict agreement with low intervention practices. 

We think that these findings are likely due to the fact that we intentionally did not design our low intervention items to be as extreme as many of our high intervention items. That is, while many of our high intervention items involved more extreme parental intervention (e.g., 'taking over' and doing work on behalf of the child), our low intervention items were intended to embody a more autonomy-supportive approach (e.g., encouraging the child to work independently, but being available for help if needed). Considering these practices on a spectrum from extremely low to extremely high parental intervention, the low intervention practices we presented to parents are quite far from the extremely low (i.e., neglectful) end of the spectrum, whereas the high intervention practices we used are relatively closer to the extremely high end of the spectrum. Because the study to which this preregistration pertains aims to replicate this pilot work (using the same high and low intervention items), our primary hypothesis follows accordingly.

H1: There will be an interaction between overall scores on a novel parent belief measure [where higher scores indicate greater endorsement of the idea that parental intervention is necessary for a young adult child’s success; items adapted from Padilla-Walker & Nelson, 2012] and type of parental practice (either high or low intervention) endorsed for specific achievement-related scenarios.

H1a: Higher scores on the belief measure will predict higher agreement with high intervention   practices.
H1b: Higher scores on the belief measure will not predict agreement with low intervention practices.

summary.value: In this set of studies, one study is focusing on perceived immorality of a target’s actions whereas the other study is focusing on perceived immorality of a target as a person. We predict that purity will have a larger mediating effect within our study of person immorality compared to action immorality.

registration_responses.summary: In this set of studies, one study is focusing on perceived immorality of a target’s actions whereas the other study is focusing on perceived immorality of a target as a person. We predict that purity will have a larger mediating effect within our study of person immorality compared to action immorality.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

analyses.value: We will conduct three independent samples t-tests to compare perceived immorality, harm, and impurity between conditions. Across these t-tests, we will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct a mediation analysis (using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R) to test whether perceived harm and/or impurity mediate the effect of COVID-19 guideline compliance behavior on perceived immorality. An effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .05. We will conduct three separate two-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) to test whether the effect of compliance condition on perceived immorality, harm, and impurity is moderated by target gender (i.e., John vs. Jane). An effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .017. If a significant interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct independent samples t-tests to test effects of condition on the relevant outcome separately for the target man and target woman. An effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .05.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in the survey.

dependent.value:
The dependent variable is perceived immorality of an abstract other. The abstract other (target) will be named “John” for half the participants and “Jane” for the other half, at random.

Perceived immorality will be assessed using the following question: “How moral or immoral is John/Jane as a person?” Ratings will range from -3 (extremely immoral) to +3 (extremely moral). This item will be scored such that 1 = extremely moral and 7 = extremely immoral.

Mediator variables include perceived harm and impurity of the target’s actions.

Perceived harm will be assessed by asking participants to rate the target in terms of how threatening, dangerous, and harmful [his/her] actions are. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely). These three items will together be computed into a perceived harm rating.

Perceived impurity will be assessed by asking participants to rate the target in terms of how disgusting, gross, filthy, unsanitary, and unhygienic [his/her] actions are. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely). These five items will together be computed into a perceived impurity rating.

The target will be introduced to participants with the statement, “We are curious to hear your attitudes toward a [man/woman] named [John/Jane].” Following this will be one of two paragraphs describing the target: a complier or non-complier.

The complier paragraph will read as follows: “[John/Jane] earns an average salary and regularly donates a moderate portion of [his/her] income to charity. [His/her] hobbies include watching movies, hiking, and playing with [his/her] young nephews and nieces. Over the past few weeks, [John/Jane] has been taking the coronavirus pandemic seriously. [He/she] has been staying home most of the time, wears a facemask when out, has socially distanced [himself/herself] from others, washes [his/her] hands frequently throughout the day, and avoids touching [his/her] face.”

The non-complier paragraph will read as follows: “[John/Jane] earns an average salary and regularly donates a moderate portion of [his/her] income to charity. [His/her] hobbies include watching movies, hiking, and playing with [his/her] young nephews and nieces. Over the past few weeks, [John/Jane] has not been taking the coronavirus pandemic seriously at all. [He/she] has been leaving home several times per day, rarely wears a facemask when out, regularly gathers in crowded areas, washes [his/her] hands only occasionally, and touches [his/her] face many times throughout the day.”

conditions.value: In terms of our main manipulation of compliance behavior, this study has 2 conditions; participants will be randomly assigned to either the complier or non-complier condition and will read the corresponding target description. As we are also randomly varying the gender of the target in addition to compliance behavior, this study uses a 2 x 2 design, with compliance (yes, no) as one factor and target gender (man, woman) as the other factor.

hypothesis.value: The aim of this research is to compare perceptions of immorality of a target who complies with COVID-19 guidelines versus a target who fails to comply, along with whether the effect of compliance on rated immorality is mediated by perceived harm and/or impurity. Aside from hypothesizing that the non-compliant target will be rated as more immoral than the compliant target, we set no specific hypotheses and instead are focusing on the preregistration of our analyses. An aim of this research is to compare competing hypotheses that the effect of compliance on rated immorality will be mediated by a) perceived harm alone or b) both perceived harm and perceived impurity. Significant mediation by only harm will provide support for the first account, whereas significant mediation by both perceived harm and impurity will provide support for the second account. We also set to explore moderation by target gender, setting no directional hypothesis.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: COVID-19 Harm-Purity 2
registration_responses.analyses: We will conduct three independent samples t-tests to compare perceived immorality, harm, and impurity between conditions. Across these t-tests, we will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct a mediation analysis (using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R) to test whether perceived harm and/or impurity mediate the effect of COVID-19 guideline compliance behavior on perceived immorality. An effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .05. We will conduct three separate two-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) to test whether the effect of compliance condition on perceived immorality, harm, and impurity is moderated by target gender (i.e., John vs. Jane). An effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .017. If a significant interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct independent samples t-tests to test effects of condition on the relevant outcome separately for the target man and target woman. An effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .05.
registration_responses.outliers: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in the survey.
registration_responses.dependent:
The dependent variable is perceived immorality of an abstract other. The abstract other (target) will be named “John” for half the participants and “Jane” for the other half, at random.

Perceived immorality will be assessed using the following question: “How moral or immoral is John/Jane as a person?” Ratings will range from -3 (extremely immoral) to +3 (extremely moral). This item will be scored such that 1 = extremely moral and 7 = extremely immoral.

Mediator variables include perceived harm and impurity of the target’s actions.

Perceived harm will be assessed by asking participants to rate the target in terms of how threatening, dangerous, and harmful [his/her] actions are. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely). These three items will together be computed into a perceived harm rating.

Perceived impurity will be assessed by asking participants to rate the target in terms of how disgusting, gross, filthy, unsanitary, and unhygienic [his/her] actions are. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely). These five items will together be computed into a perceived impurity rating.

The target will be introduced to participants with the statement, “We are curious to hear your attitudes toward a [man/woman] named [John/Jane].” Following this will be one of two paragraphs describing the target: a complier or non-complier.

The complier paragraph will read as follows: “[John/Jane] earns an average salary and regularly donates a moderate portion of [his/her] income to charity. [His/her] hobbies include watching movies, hiking, and playing with [his/her] young nephews and nieces. Over the past few weeks, [John/Jane] has been taking the coronavirus pandemic seriously. [He/she] has been staying home most of the time, wears a facemask when out, has socially distanced [himself/herself] from others, washes [his/her] hands frequently throughout the day, and avoids touching [his/her] face.”

The non-complier paragraph will read as follows: “[John/Jane] earns an average salary and regularly donates a moderate portion of [his/her] income to charity. [His/her] hobbies include watching movies, hiking, and playing with [his/her] young nephews and nieces. Over the past few weeks, [John/Jane] has not been taking the coronavirus pandemic seriously at all. [He/she] has been leaving home several times per day, rarely wears a facemask when out, regularly gathers in crowded areas, washes [his/her] hands only occasionally, and touches [his/her] face many times throughout the day.”

An aim of this research is to compare competing hypotheses that the effect of compliance on rated immorality will be mediated by a) perceived harm alone or b) both perceived harm and perceived impurity. Significant mediation by only harm will provide support for the first account, whereas significant mediation by both perceived harm and impurity will provide support for the second account. We also set to explore moderation by target gender, setting no directional hypothesis.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

analyses.value:
We will conduct two independent samples t-tests—one for each attitude outcome: 1) global attitude and 2) manager approval—to test whether participants’ attitudes toward the handshaking manager differ from attitude toward the non-handshaking manager. As secondary analyses, we will conduct three independent samples t-tests—one for each attitude mediator: 1) perceived sociability, 2) morality, and 3) competence—to test whether participants’ attitudes toward the handshaking manager differ from attitude toward the non-handshaking manager in these regards. Across these t-tests, we will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct two separate mediation analyses (using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R) to test whether perceived sociability, morality, and/or competence mediate the effect of handshaking behavior on 1) global attitude and 2) manager approval. We will conduct two separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude is moderated by political ideology. For each regression, we will regress the outcome (i.e., global attitude or approval) on political ideology, condition, and the interaction term for political ideology and condition. For the above tests, an effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .05.

We will conduct two separate two-way analyses of variance (ANOVAs) to test whether the effect of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude is moderated by participant gender. If a significant interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct independent samples t-tests to test effects of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude among men and women separately. We will conduct two separate two-way ANOVAs to test whether the effect of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude is moderated by target gender (i.e., John vs. Jane). If a significant interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct independent samples t-tests to test effects of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude toward the manager man and manager woman separately. For these gender moderation tests, an effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .01.

outliers.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they fail an attention check in the survey. Participants who indicate that they are neither a man nor woman will be excluded from analyses testing moderation by participant gender.

dependent.value:
Dependent variables include two measures of attitude toward a businessperson, specifically a manager: global attitude and manager approval. The manager will be named “John” for half the participants and “Jane” for the other half, at random.

Mediator variables include perceived sociability, morality, and competence of the manager.

Global attitude toward the manager will be assessed using the following attitude thermometer item: “Please move the slider below to indicate how favorably you feel toward this manager.” Ratings will range from 1 (extremely unfavorable) to 10 (extremely favorable).

Manager approval will be assessed by the following 4 items: “I approve of this person’s behavior as manager,” “This manager runs [his/her] division well,” “More managers should act like this person,” and “This manager is a good leader of [his/her] division.” Responses will range from 1 (strongly disagree) to 7 (strongly agree).

Perceived sociability of the manager will be assessed by asking participants to rate the manager in terms of how “kind,” “warm,” “friendly,” “likeable,” and “good-natured” [he/she] is. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely).

Perceived morality of the manager will be assessed by asking participants to rate the manager in terms of how “moral,” “honest,” “sincere,” “trustworthy,” and “well-intentioned” [he/she] is. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely).

Perceived competence of the manager will be assessed by asking participants to rate the manager in terms of how “competent,” “confident,” “intelligent,” “skillful,” “capable,” and “efficient” [he/she] is. Each trait will be rated on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 7 (extremely).

Handshaking behavior will be manipulated by assigning participants to randomly read one of the following descriptions of a manager, with the names “John” and “Jane” randomly varying across description conditions. The full text of the non-handshaking condition appears below in normal font throughout. In the handshaking condition, the last two sentences will be replaced with the italicized text in parentheses: “John/Jane is the manager of a large division at his/her company. John/Jane became manager only 6 months ago but has worked in this division for the past 15 years. John/Jane has led his/her division reasonably well so far this year, reporting earnings that are in line with expectations. Because of the coronavirus pandemic, John/Jane has decided to refrain from shaking hands with any business partners or employees during the upcoming months. John/Jane recognizes coronavirus guidelines and will continue conducting business without shaking hands until concerns about the coronavirus are resolved. (Despite the coronavirus pandemic, John/Jane has decided to continue shaking hands with business partners and employees during the upcoming months. John/Jane recognizes coronavirus guidelines but believes that handshaking is a core part of conducting business.)”

Gender will be assessed by the item, “Please select your gender,” with responses including “Man,” “Woman,” “Non-Binary,” and “Other.”

Political ideology will be assessed by the following question: “On the following scale from 1 (very liberal) to 7 (very conservative), how would you rate your political views?”

conditions.value: In terms of our main manipulation of handshaking behavior, this study has 2 conditions; participants will be randomly assigned to either the handshaker or non-handshaker condition and will read the corresponding target description. As we are also randomly varying the gender of the target in addition to handshaking behavior, this study uses a 2 x 2 design, with handshaking (yes, no) as one factor and target gender (man, woman) as the other factor.

hypothesis.value: This study will address the following question: How does a businessperson’s decision to shake hands or not during the months following the COVID-19 pandemic’s emergence affect how the businessperson is perceived? We hypothesize that people will evaluate a businessperson who refrains from shaking hands more positively than a businessperson who does shake hands. We hypothesize that the effect of handshaking behavior on evaluation will be mediated by perceptions of the businessperson’s competence and morality, such that a non-handshaking businessperson will be rated as more competent and moral than a handshaking businessperson. We hypothesize that the effect of handshaking behavior on evaluation will be moderated by political ideology, such that the effect of refraining from handshaking on how a businessperson is evaluated will be less positive among participants who are more politically conservative relative to liberal. We also set to explore moderation by participant gender and target gender, setting no directional hypotheses.

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: COVID-19 Handshaking
registration_responses.analyses:
We will conduct two independent samples t-tests—one for each attitude outcome: 1) global attitude and 2) manager approval—to test whether participants’ attitudes toward the handshaking manager differ from attitude toward the non-handshaking manager. As secondary analyses, we will conduct three independent samples t-tests—one for each attitude mediator: 1) perceived sociability, 2) morality, and 3) competence—to test whether participants’ attitudes toward the handshaking manager differ from attitude toward the non-handshaking manager in these regards. Across these t-tests, we will conduct Welch-adjusted t-tests when a Levene’s test indicates unequal variances (p < .05) between groups. We will conduct two separate mediation analyses (using path analysis via structural equation modeling with the lavaan package in R) to test whether perceived sociability, morality, and/or competence mediate the effect of handshaking behavior on 1) global attitude and 2) manager approval. We will conduct two separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude is moderated by political ideology. For each regression, we will regress the outcome (i.e., global attitude or approval) on political ideology, condition, and the interaction term for political ideology and condition. For the above tests, an effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .05.

We will conduct two separate two-way analyses of variance (ANOVAs) to test whether the effect of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude is moderated by participant gender. If a significant interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct independent samples t-tests to test effects of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude among men and women separately. We will conduct two separate two-way ANOVAs to test whether the effect of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude is moderated by target gender (i.e., John vs. Jane). If a significant interaction effect emerges, then we will conduct independent samples t-tests to test effects of handshaking behavior on each measure of attitude toward the manager man and manager woman separately. For these gender moderation tests, an effect will be considered significant if it yields a p-value less than .01.

attributes.title: Systematic review of prediction models for tuberculosis treatment outcomes
attributes.description: This systematic review rigorously evaluates tuberculosis (TB) outcome prediction models, evaluating their risk of bias and generalizability to other populations. The results serve as guidance for future studies that develop TB outcome predictions and can inform interventions to promote cure among patients at highest risk of unsuccessful TB outcomes.

q1.value: Lauren Peetluk, Felipe Ridolfi, Peter Rebeiro, Dandan Liu, Valeria Rolla, Timothy Sterling

q2.value:
This is a descriptive systematic review, and hypothesis testing is not directly relevant. 

Primary objectives:
1)	Identify existing prediction models for pulmonary TB treatment outcomes.
2)	Qualitatively summarize the characteristics of each study.
3)	Compare the reported metrics of predictive performance (calibration, discrimination, and validation) from each model, and if possible, meta-analyze the model performance statistics across studies.
4)	Assess the risk of bias and evaluate the applicability of each prediction model with the Prediction Model Risk of Bias Assessment Tool (PROBAST). 

Secondary objectives:
1)	Evaluate how each study operationalizes the definition of TB treatment outcome
2)	Evaluate how each study operationalizes HIV status.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: At present, study screening is underway, but the study was registered prior to data extraction.

question.value:
The main search was carried out in PubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and Google Scholar (first 200 relevant references). Clinicaltrials.gov, and retractiondatabase.org were also searched for unpublished research. In addition, the reference lists of retrieved articles and relevant reviews were checked to identify other eligible studies. 

The following inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied: 

Inclusion criteria: 
-	Prognostic model studies with or without external validation, and external model validation studies with or without model updating 
-	Study population includes adult, drug-susceptible, pulmonary, TB cases
-	Articles published in English, Spanish, Portuguese, and French
-	Published after January 1, 1995
-	Predicted treatment outcome is at least one of the following: cure, treatment completion, death, treatment failure, loss to follow-up, or not evaluated, treatment success, unsuccessful treatment

Exclusion criteria: 
-	The predictive value of more than one variable was evaluated but not combined in a prediction model
-	Study population is only multi-drug resistant TB cases 
-	Study population is only extrapulmonary TB cases
-	Study population is only children
-	Diagnostic prediction model
-	Predicted outcome is evaluated during treatment such as: two-month smear or culture conversion, acquired resistance, toxicity, adverse events, adherence, quality of life
-	Prognostic model for long-term outcomes, such as relapse, recurrence, or post-treatment mortality 

The main outcome of interest is the unsuccessful TB treatment outcome, defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as the combination of death, treatment failure, loss to follow-up, and/or not evaluated, as compared to successful TB treatment outcome, defined as the combination of cure and treatment completion. Included studies should evaluate at least one of the following outcomes: cure, treatment completion, death, treatment failure, loss to follow-up, or not evaluated. Loss to follow-up is sometimes referred to as default or treatment abandonment. Not evaluated includes cases who transfer out, move, or have unknown outcomes. Some prediction models will look at only single endpoints, whereas other look at composite outcomes. 

The article selection process will proceed through four stages by two independent reviewers. Any discordance will be resolved by a third party. First, titles will be screened in
Rmarkdown to exclude titles that are clearly irrelevant (ex. bovine, case study, mouse model, contact tracing). The list of exclusion criteria will be made available with final
publication. Second, two reviewers will screen abstracts of remaining articles (Stage 2). Then for articles that make it past the abstract screening, full-texts will be screened 
(Stage 3) and data will be extracted from relevant studies (Stage 4). Stages 2 and 3 will be carried out with Covidence, the primary screening and data extraction tool for Cochrane
authors. Stage 3 will be carried out in REDCap with a data extraction form developed specifically for this review.

Data extraction in REDCap is informed by the CHecklist for critical Appraisal and data extraction for systematic Reviews of prediction Modelling Studies (CHARMS).

Quality assessment and applicability of included studies will be assessed using the Prediction model Risk Of Bias Assessment Tool (PROBAST) on the data extraction form in REDCap. 

More details are available in the protocol and supplemental files.

q11.value: The search strategy (through January 9, 2020) yielded 6,327 articles in PubMed, 10,825 in Embase, 10,707 in Web of Science, and 200 from Google Scholar, totaling 28,059 articles. After de-duplication, 14,736 articles remained. After reviewing titles and abstracts, 534 articles remained and are currently undergoing full text review to identify the final list of included studies.

question.value: In brief, data extraction elements include publication details, participant descriptions, outcomes, predictors, sample size, missing data, model development, model performance, model evaluation, results, and interpretation. Data will be extracted according to the full CHARMS checklist is provided in the file below.

The results of studies will be summarized with narrative review in detailed tables and with descriptive statistics. At minimum, two tables will be presented. The first will summarize key study characteristics of each prediction model included, such as study location, time frame, population, outcome definition, prevalence of HIV, predictors included, model selection techniques, and model performance. The second table will summarize the results from PROBAST, grading each domain (participants, predictors, outcomes, analysis) as low risk, high risk, or unclear risk of bias.  

If multiple studies use the same prediction model or there are external validation studies that apply an existing prediction model to a new population, formal meta-analysis of the predictive performance of each model will be conducted. Through meta-analysis, summary measures of model performance (i.e., calibration, discrimination) will be computed, depending on what measure reported in each study. If the c-statistic (recommended discrimination measure) is not available, it is possible to estimate the c-statistic and its standard error from Somer’s D statistic, the distribution of the linear predictor, the log-odds ratio of the linear predictor, and Cohen’s effect size. Because calibration plots are hard to combine across studies, we would use information on total observed and total expected events to compute an observed to expected ratio, which can estimate the overall model calibration.

Because heterogeneity between studies will be likely due to differences in design, methods, and population, a random effects meta-analysis model will be used to calculate pooled measures of discrimination and calibration and their 95% confidence intervals. Publication bias will be assessed with funnel plots and Egger’s test. Heterogeneity between studies will be assessed using Cochran’s Q statistic to estimate the I-squared value, which describes the percentage variation across studies that is due to heterogeneity, rather than chance.

registration_responses.q1: Lauren Peetluk, Felipe Ridolfi, Peter Rebeiro, Dandan Liu, Valeria Rolla, Timothy Sterling
registration_responses.q2:
This is a descriptive systematic review, and hypothesis testing is not directly relevant. 

Primary objectives:
1)	Identify existing prediction models for pulmonary TB treatment outcomes.
2)	Qualitatively summarize the characteristics of each study.
3)	Compare the reported metrics of predictive performance (calibration, discrimination, and validation) from each model, and if possible, meta-analyze the model performance statistics across studies.
4)	Assess the risk of bias and evaluate the applicability of each prediction model with the Prediction Model Risk of Bias Assessment Tool (PROBAST). 

Secondary objectives:
1)	Evaluate how each study operationalizes the definition of TB treatment outcome
2)	Evaluate how each study operationalizes HIV status.
registration_responses.q3: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q4: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q9: At present, study screening is underway, but the study was registered prior to data extraction.
registration_responses.q11: The search strategy (through January 9, 2020) yielded 6,327 articles in PubMed, 10,825 in Embase, 10,707 in Web of Science, and 200 from Google Scholar, totaling 28,059 articles. After de-duplication, 14,736 articles remained. After reviewing titles and abstracts, 534 articles remained and are currently undergoing full text review to identify the final list of included studies.
registration_responses.q6.question: Systematic review
registration_responses.q10.question:
The main search was carried out in PubMed, Embase, Web of Science, and Google Scholar (first 200 relevant references). Clinicaltrials.gov, and retractiondatabase.org were also searched for unpublished research. In addition, the reference lists of retrieved articles and relevant reviews were checked to identify other eligible studies. 

The following inclusion and exclusion criteria were applied: 

Inclusion criteria: 
-	Prognostic model studies with or without external validation, and external model validation studies with or without model updating 
-	Study population includes adult, drug-susceptible, pulmonary, TB cases
-	Articles published in English, Spanish, Portuguese, and French
-	Published after January 1, 1995
-	Predicted treatment outcome is at least one of the following: cure, treatment completion, death, treatment failure, loss to follow-up, or not evaluated, treatment success, unsuccessful treatment

Exclusion criteria: 
-	The predictive value of more than one variable was evaluated but not combined in a prediction model
-	Study population is only multi-drug resistant TB cases 
-	Study population is only extrapulmonary TB cases
-	Study population is only children
-	Diagnostic prediction model
-	Predicted outcome is evaluated during treatment such as: two-month smear or culture conversion, acquired resistance, toxicity, adverse events, adherence, quality of life
-	Prognostic model for long-term outcomes, such as relapse, recurrence, or post-treatment mortality 

The main outcome of interest is the unsuccessful TB treatment outcome, defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as the combination of death, treatment failure, loss to follow-up, and/or not evaluated, as compared to successful TB treatment outcome, defined as the combination of cure and treatment completion. Included studies should evaluate at least one of the following outcomes: cure, treatment completion, death, treatment failure, loss to follow-up, or not evaluated. Loss to follow-up is sometimes referred to as default or treatment abandonment. Not evaluated includes cases who transfer out, move, or have unknown outcomes. Some prediction models will look at only single endpoints, whereas other look at composite outcomes.

Rmarkdown to exclude titles that are clearly irrelevant (ex. bovine, case study, mouse model, contact tracing). The list of exclusion criteria will be made available with final
publication. Second, two reviewers will screen abstracts of remaining articles (Stage 2). Then for articles that make it past the abstract screening, full-texts will be screened 
(Stage 3) and data will be extracted from relevant studies (Stage 4). Stages 2 and 3 will be carried out with Covidence, the primary screening and data extraction tool for Cochrane
authors. Stage 3 will be carried out in REDCap with a data extraction form developed specifically for this review.

Data extraction in REDCap is informed by the CHecklist for critical Appraisal and data extraction for systematic Reviews of prediction Modelling Studies (CHARMS).

Quality assessment and applicability of included studies will be assessed using the Prediction model Risk Of Bias Assessment Tool (PROBAST) on the data extraction form in REDCap. 

More details are available in the protocol and supplemental files.
